body:
I try to add  another loss to the googlenet, but when I use the api of ImageRecordIO ,I found
ImageRecordIO only can  input one label_name , maybe "softmax1_label" or "softmax2_label",
but how can I add the two at the same time,  with the same label but different label name?
@pluskid
Thanks
Thanks for the PR! We are currently working on Inception-7. Once it is ready, current full bn network be replaced by Inception-7 directly.
cool
I also want to see such guidance. I just switched from Caffe to MXNet but implementing a new layer is a pain in the neck here compared to the abstraction provided by Caffe.
I'm just wondering what batch size was used for generating the graph on the website.
You can do this by subclassing mx.io.DataIter. It's pretty easy to write your own iterator

Yes, we do need a tutorial for this. However we are currently short handed as half of the team is going to NIPS and it's X'mas after that. Any help on this is welcome.

Here is the set of documents that's missing:
How to create your own DataIter
How to create your own model
How to create your own C++ layer
How to solve your own model.

Again, we really appreciate any help on making MXNet easier to use. Please feel free to share your experiences.
Please refer to this guide: https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/developer-guide/operator.html Hope this helps.
@antinucleon OK, I got it
@mli @tqchen

Thanks.
@antinucleon let's still merge this pr first
That's possible since kvstore has extra memory copy. But what kind of nn and hardware you are using?

@piiswrong Thank you for your response. I believe the listed documents are crucial for those who want to use mxnet for research purpose, which will surely make mxnet a more powerful and wide used tool.
Often set -n to be the number of gpu machines you have. But you can set -s to a larger number , eg 2n. But the weights updating is often quite simple, 30% seems normal to me
@GravApple I suggest you to read through the examples in mshadow folder.

alexnet+TitanX. I changed --kv-store from 'local' to 'local_allreduce_device' and speed bumped from 350samples/s to 700samples/s. Looks like local_allreduce_device is missing from kvstore.create('local')
Don't bind the gradient for the weights that you don't want to update

Maybe we should change softmax to take a symbol instead of having a fixed label name. It would also be more consistent with the regression outputs. Additionally if no symbol is provided we could automatically insert a symbol with the name `softmax_label`

@piiswrong I've updated the codes and installed again. However the problem is still there. If I try the complete 'simple_bind' example, there is no error. So I guess maybe there are some bugs of allocating or freeing memory.

@piiswrong 
Thank you very much for your response. The problem is solved.

# 

Before closing this issue, I have another question about the backwards process of logistic regression. I find the following code in `src/operator/regression_output.cc`

```
case reg_enum::kLogistic:
      return new RegressionOutputOp<cpu, mshadow_op::sigmoid, mshadow::op::minus>();
```

As you use `minus` as the `BackwardOp`, then I am curious in which place you deal with the gradient of `sigmoid`? Please let me know if I misunderstand something.

You are probably missing some DLLs. You will need to add the path to all
the dependent DLLs to you PATH. For example, if you use OpenBLAS, then
libopenblas.dll should be in your PATH, same as OpenCV and cuDNN.

## 

HONG Chuntao
System Research Group
Microsoft Research Asia

@GravApple sigmoid has the nice property that it's derivative is just y - l

And no, you don't have to do it like that. Which dataiter are you using? NDArrayIter takes a dictionary and you can change output name with it. Other iters have `data_name='data', label_name='softmax_label'` as default argument and you can change it.
use callbacks in mx.callbacks.py

What do you mean by C++ interface is not properly exposed? What changes do we need?

BTW, a Makefile for your C++ example should be a good start. Unfortunately I'm not good with makefiles. Maybe @mli can help
Can you run any example with GPU? a quick work around is to fit with end_epoch=0 so that FeedFoward model can bind for you without training

1. C++ interface cannot be directly exposed in DLL/.so files, since the
   compilation environment might be different when compiling libmxnet and when
   compiling applications, leading to application crash due to ABI violations.
   This of course can be solved by forcing the user to always compile mxnet
   from source and use the same environment to compile application, but not
   really desirable: building libmxnet is painfully slow.
2. The C api is a minimum interface. It provides apis such as
   CreateSymbols(char*, ...), instead of mx.sym.FullyConnect(...) as provided
   in Python. So users has to lookup the symbols first, which currently is not
   documented at all. I think we should wrap those libraries so they look more
   like Python interface.

I am not familiar with Cmake either. That's why I haven't written it for
the example. :-P

need cuDNN library.

2. open VS, then open the solution (VS must be started after you run
setupenv.cmd, or it won't load the PATH environment variable correclty)
3. if using cuDNN, put cudnn64_xx.dll into 3rdparty/cudnn. Make sure the
cudnn DLL file is in 3rdparty/cudnn/bin
4. build and run the program

I see. VS is trying to load the debug symbols for the system DLLs. You can
see it from the "Output" window. If you wait for long enough, it will
eventually finish and enter the main function. This usually takes around a
minute or so, depending on your environment.

You can get rid of this behavior by undefining the "_NT_SYMBOL_PATH"
environment variable. Go to "My Computer"->"Properties"->"Advanced system
settings"->"Environment Variables"->"System variables", find
"_NT_SYMBOL_PATH", and then click "delete". Then, restart your VS, and it
should work just fine.

@tqchen It's also happening to me. Probably is a bug. I think the recent changes cause bad choices for KVStore reduce methods. In addition batch_size is affecting speed in an unpredictable way (batchsize=16 => 260samples/s, batchsize=32 => 90 smaples/s. this may be irrelevent to this, I just found that when batchsize=32 kernel transpose_readWrite_alignment_kernel suddenly popped up and takes a lot of time. So probably a CUDNN conv method issue). @mli Could you look into it?

Ok now I get it. This is a harmless error. It's because mxnet exited before it's fully initialized. Do something after bind and you'll be fine, like start training/predicting or simply time.sleep(10)

@tqchen this is the singleton destruction bug we talked about. Could you fix it or at least hide it?
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/865
Thanks for the contribution. Will merge after test finishes

hi, @hjk41 1. I use the following cmake setup, with your code, and I think this is a general setup for other tasks(this works for linux only). Just add them to the tail of the original Makefile. ``` COMPILE_com=$(CXX) -std=c++0x $(CFLAGS) -L./lib -lmxnet $(LDFLAGS) -I ./src example_cpp: example/cpp/use_ndarray.cpp lib/libmxnet.a lib/libmxnet.so $(COMPILE_com) -o $@ $(filter %.cpp %.o %.c %.a %.cc, $^) example_cpp_run: example_cpp LD_LIBRARY_PATH=./lib ./example_cpp ``` and ,of course, run as the following:
make example_cpp_run
2. Do we need to compile the whole mxnet everytime? Just using the heads in ./include and the compiled libraries libmxnet.a/libmxnet.so should be ok. Also, maybe the heads in ./src is needed because the operators are defined there. However, I haven't made any advancement in using CPP-version-mxnet by now yet. But again, is it that necessary to try to do all the work in C/CPP, Python just does well.
And it cannot solved by using steps like 'start training/predicting or simply time.sleep(10)' from [865](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/865).

@piiswrong 
My 'image.lst'  TXT  file is created by MATLAB. I have checked this file  and found no problem. If ignoring the check,I can run my model with GPU, but the train accuracy drops gradually.
